entries.content: Get the prospect to discover they have a problem themselves, rather than telling them.
Avoid telling prospects their current process is 'stupid' or bad, as this will upset them.
Standard factual questions (who, what, where, why, how) are insufficient; they gather facts but don't create emotional realization of pain.
Focus on making facts and figures 'hurt' emotionally for the prospect, not just presenting them intellectually.
Use presumptive questions to get prospects to explain why they haven't already adopted a better solution or resolved an issue.
entries.notes: Presumes a desirable alternative exists and prompts them to explain their deviation.

entries.content: "Can I ask you a question, when you were offered the opportunity to automate this... why did you say no to it?"
entries.notes: Example of a presumptive question framing automation as a missed opportunity.

entries.content: "when you turn to your sales guys and you ask them why aren't you hitting target what did they say? ... do you believe those excuses are valid?"
entries.notes: Example of presumptive questions prompting reflection on internal issues.

focus_area: Competitive Objections: Unique value framing without attacking others
